Key Arguments: The bill threatens freedom of speech and democratic values.
It creates an imbalance of power by privileging certain groups like politicians and journalists.
Excessive fines will lead to over-censorship by digital services.
The bill targets not only false information but also true information deemed misleading.
It risks becoming anti-competitive by empowering dominant digital services.
The bill is inconsistent with the News Media Bargaining Code.
It poses a threat to minorities and their ability to participate in public discourse.
Delegating power to private entities raises constitutional concerns.
The bill could lead to a biased media landscape by categorizing political viewpoints as misinformation.
Notable Quotes: The Internet is a remarkable tool that empowers regular citizens to participate in open and honest discussions.
The potential for censorship under this bill is deeply concerning and contradicts the claim of being on the side of truth and not censorship.
The bill's categorization of political party viewpoints as misinformation not only hinders the democratic process but also perpetuates a biased media landscape.
